terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Colombian Andes. Extreme elevation with mountain scenery at high altitude.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Colombian event. Extreme Andes terrain with difficult access, high costs, high altitude, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Transcordilleras is a regional event in Colombian Andes—extreme mountainous terrain with massive elevation at high altitude. The Colombian Andes are stunning, but the difficult/expensive access, extreme altitude, and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: An extreme Colombian Andes mountain gravel race with altitude challenge. Worth it for elite adventure seekers with big budgets. Not practical for most riders.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you have a big budget and want an extreme Colombian experience—maybe. For most riders—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: regional gravel races. For similar Colombian terrain: Gravel Bogotá.

logistics.airport: Bogotá (BOG) or Medellín (MDE) varies by location
logistics.lodging_strategy: Colombian Andes has limited lodging options. Plan ahead.

suffering_zones.label: Late Andes
suffering_zones.desc: Final Andes mountain sections before finish.

course_description.signature_challenge: Colombian Andes extreme mountainous terrain at altitude.

non_negotiables.why: Extreme altitude (8000+ feet) requires serious altitude adaptation.
Colombian Andes extreme mountains require sustained effort.

topics.pacing: Extreme mountainous terrain pacing at altitude
topics.fueling: Nutrition for extreme altitude mountain riding

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event with extreme mountainous terrain at altitude.

logistics.explanation: Starts in Paipa, Boyacá with minimal infrastructure support. Griffin Easter found himself rationing half a bottle through Chichamocha Canyon after losing hydration early. Race is self-supported with GPS navigation through rural Colombia where Janosch Wintermantel discovered bike shop owners "had simply never put his hand on any electronic gears before."

length.explanation: Griffin Easter noted "the 1,030 km route was not what scared me, it was the 21,500m of climbing." Eight stages across Colombian mountain ranges with conservative GC tactics required - Easter held back on stage wins to "stay consistent" for overall victory. Julian Manrique took 23 hours just to reach the first checkpoint in Salento. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: Janosch Wintermantel warns "Colombian gravel is not comparable to the smooth surface most of us are used to in Europe or the US." Griffin Easter found Stage 2 "marked as 45% paved and 55% gravel, that proved false. The day was actually closer to 95% gravel" with gradients hitting 28%. Cristian Yepes needed a hardtail mountain bike to handle the technical descents. More technical than most — comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

elevation.explanation: Sumapaz páramo features two separate climbs to 3850m - "more than 1000 meters higher than the mighty Col d'Iseran," notes Janosch Wintermantel. The Queen Stage delivers 13,300 feet of climbing in a single day. Alto del Sifón spans 60 miles with 13,000 feet of gain, earning its reputation as the world's longest paved climb. Among the hilliest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

climate.explanation: February brings hot, humid Colombian weather that adds serious challenge to multi-day suffering. Shifting climate zones daily from high-altitude páramos to jungle valleys means you'll cook in multiple ways. Heat and humidity don't forgive. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Chingaza National Park section runs above 10,000 feet for 40 miles through páramo ecosystem. Iris experienced altitude effects above 3000 meters: "The lack of oxygen makes you feel dizzy and just weird in general." Austin Sullivan described "riding above 10,000 feet for the middle 40 miles of the day dictated the pace" through fog-shrouded frailejon plants. Higher altitude racing, comparable to SBT GRVL.

adventure.explanation: Self-supported bikepacking through three Colombian mountain ranges, colonial towns, and ever-changing landscapes from páramos to jungle. Riders call it an incredible window into South American gravel with pure cultural immersion. This is adventure in its purest form.

prestige.explanation: This is a nobody's-heard-of-it event in Colombia's cycling heartland. No known pro riders, no race history available, no global recognition. One rider called it "one of the coolest bike-experiences of my life" but that doesn't translate to prestige points in the gravel world hierarchy.

race_quality.explanation: Self-supported bikepacking with GPS navigation and daily checkpoints sounds organized, but the logistics info is basically non-existent. No entry fees, field size, cutoff times, or aid station details available.

experience.explanation: Iris captures the essence: "It might not have been the most relaxed holiday, but sometimes it's just THE BEST to go home with an empty body and a full heart. Colombia and its people have definitely secured a place in mine." Riders traverse Magdalena River Valley, witness golden sunsets, and experience pure cultural immersion across eight transformative stages.

community.explanation: Annemiek van Vleuten helped broker pace agreements during the Queen Stage, with Iris noting "there was always one of us that could encourage the other." Laurens ten Dam praised Colombian hospitality: "Everyone is so nice here in Colombia. I haven't met a single grumpy person." Field size reaches 100 riders but lacks deep community roots of established races.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 200-400 riders, no field size data, no notable past winners, no pro participation mentioned. This attracts adventure seekers, not competitive depth. One rider noted it's "more difficult than anything encountered in U.S. events" but that doesn't mean fast riders show up. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Eight stages through Colombia's cycling heartland offers cultural immersion impossible elsewhere. Race director Mauricio Ordonez promotes local economy in forgotten mountain towns. However, international logistics and self-supported requirements create significant hidden costs beyond entry fees, with no detailed pricing breakdown available for the 1,030km journey.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $150-250. International flight to Colombia, eight days of self-supported travel, gear shipping, and whatever they charge for entry. No cost breakdown available but getting to Paipa, Boyacá and surviving 1,000km of bikepacking won't be cheap. More expensive than Atlas Mountain Race.

primary.why: Technical terrain dominator. Aggressive grip when the course gets rowdy.

primary.name: Maxxis Reaver
primary.why: Technical all-rounder. EXO+ casing shrugs off rocks and roots.

primary.why: Soft-terrain specialist. Open knob pattern sheds mud and grips wet rock.

videos.title: Andean Grit, Transcordilleras 2025, 8 stage gravel race, Colombia.
videos.description:
Endurance adventurers Mark and Caroline Livesey return to Colombia for their second time to tackle this epic eight-day gravel race.  Transcordilleras, Colombia, is without doubt one of the most gruelling gravel stage races in the world. 

From extreme weather to never-ending mountain passes, some over 4000m in altitude, each day pushes their limits physically and mentally in jaw-dropping landscapes.  Alongside the pain, a familiar theme emerges: the joyous hospitality of the Colombian people. 

On and off the gravel, this film highlights how Colombians—proud, welcoming, and endlessly resourceful—empower the riders. Whether helping fix punctures at roadside shops or improvising mechanical solutions in remote locations, their generosity becomes the emotional backbone of the competition. Both the Colombian competitors and the locals along the route inject kindness, which creates a unique experience for the riders. 

Beyond the landscape, the documentary reveals a deep camaraderie among the competitors. Bonding through shared struggles, riders from around the globe—from professional cyclists to weekend warriors—form friendships that will endure long after the finish line.

videos.curation_reason: Most recent first-person race recap from 2025 with detailed experiential content from returning participants.

videos.title: TRANSCORDILLERAS - Gravel Racing in Colombia
videos.description:
Transcordilleras is a grueling 1035km (21,000m elevation) gravel bike race through the Andes of Colombia. The race has a non-stop version, but also an 8-day stage race which is the race Caroline and Mark attempted in 2024. With severe heat, high altitude, unforgiving terrain, and rough surfaces; this race had it all. But the pain and suffering was eclipsed by the warmth and hospitality of the Colombian people. They built lasting friendships, and never tired of the incredible views and raw beauty of the landscape. 
This is a race which has been built by a team who love to explore. Hear about how it grew from friends bikepacking together, and continues to grow internationally now as gravel enthusiasts seek adventures in this country where cycling is as much part of the culture as coffee. With a route that changes every year, always taking the competitors to different areas of the mountains, this is one that should be on every endurance adventurers bucketlist.

videos.title: Transcordilleras: Going Far Beyond in Colombia with Lachlan Morton (Full Film)
videos.channel: Far Beyond by EF Pro Cycling
videos.description:
“If you viewed it exclusively through a competitive lens you would just miss a lot. You’d probably be in bed earlier or, like, be more stressed about trying to recover or, you know, pushing with your head down a bit more during the race. [You’d] miss a lot of what the experience has to offer.”

For Lachy, taking on the eight stages of Transcordilleras was about racing his bike. But it was equally about taking in the Colombian landscape, pushing himself and his competitors, and experiencing every stage of the race like a bikepacking trip.

Join Lachlan Morton and Far Beyond for our first episode: Transcordilleras going Far Beyond in Colombia. 

00:00 Intro
00:54 Welcome to Bogota 
07:55 Pre-Race
09:23 Stage 1
12:42 Stage 2
14:57 Stage 3
16:45 Stage 4
18:25 Stage 5
20:18 Stage 6
21:43 Stage 7
23:34 Stage 8

Subscribe to Far Beyond to catch every new episode: https://www.youtube.com/@FarBeyond-EFPC

#efprocycling #cycling #gravelbike #colombia #transcordilleras

videos.curation_reason: Professional quality documentary featuring pro cyclist Lachlan Morton with excellent production values and recent content from 2025.

videos.title: UNA CHIMBA - A Colombian gravel documentary
videos.description:
The most insane and intense self supported bike packing rally in Colombia: Transcordilleras. Watch the battle between frenemies Laurens ten Dam and Peter Stetina on the unforgiving but mindblowing gravel roads of Colombia. It's them vs the Colombian Andes Mountains, up up up & down, 8 days long.

Special thanks to PRO BIKEGEAR for working together on this project!

For English, Spanish and Dutch subtitles, go to 'settings' bottom right of the video.

WANT MORE LIVE SLOW RIDE FAST?
Check out www.liveslowridefast.com

WANT TO RIDE IN THE SAME SWAG AS THE TEAM?
Check out www.lsrf.cc

----

El rally de bicicletas autosuficientes más loco e intenso de Colombia: Transcordilleras. Mira la batalla entre los amigos-enemigos Laurens ten Dam y Peter Stetina en los implacables pero alucinantes caminos de grava de Colombia. Son ellos contra la Cordillera de los Andes colombianos, arriba arriba y abajo, 8 días de duración.

¡Un agradecimiento especial a PRO BIKEGEAR por trabajar juntos en este proyecto!

Para subtítulos en inglés, español y holandés, verifique la configuración.

¿QUIERES MÁS VIVE SLOW RIDE RÁPIDO?
Echa un vistazo a www.liveslowridefast.com

¿QUIERES VIAJAR EN EL MISMO SWAG QUE EL EQUIPO?
Echa un vistazo a www.lsrf.cc

videos.curation_reason: High-production documentary with strong view count featuring pro cyclists ten Dam and Stetina, showcasing the race's intensity despite being from 2022.

videos.title: Laurens ten Dam's Transcordilleras-winning bike & strategy for 1,000 Colombian gravel KMs in 3 days
videos.description:
Transcordilleras is a bikepacking gravel race in Colombia. There are 3 events: a 3-day stage race, an 8-day stage race, and the 1,000km non-stop, where participants can go as far as they can each day, sleeping wherever they decide. Former Tour de France top-10 finisher Laurens ten Dam came to Colombia with a Specialized S-Works Epic mountain bike equipped with a Shimano GRX gravel drivetrain, road handlebars and aero extensions - plus *two* Wahoo Elemnt computers, just in case...

He won the race in record time, sleeping just over 7 hour for the entirety of the competition that took races high into the Andes with some 66,000ft of climbing, and down into the sweltering lowlands.

I caught up with Laurens at the finish in Santa Fe Antioquia.

Still photos courtesy Transcordilleras and BikeRadar.

-

quotes.text: At the end of the day it's kind of a bike packing trip more so than a race even. I mean you're still riding super hard and pushing each other, but more than that you're also just completing some pretty epic pieces of road pushing through some pretty unique landscapes.
quotes.source_channel: Far Beyond by EF Pro Cycling

quotes.text: This year we went up into the Paramo. We had more high altitude riding which created its own challenges. The Paramo in Colombia is mountains that are above 3,000m and they have a very special flora and fauna. The climate is different. It's much cooler up there.

Two and a half hours, 3 hours into the race of day one I was like I've not seen gravel like this, I've not felt heat like this and I had my bike on my shoulder thinking holy shit I've got eight more days of this.

key_challenges.name: Ride to Puerto Berrio
key_challenges.description: Described as the worst part of the race, extremely hot conditions around 3pm with temperatures reaching a thousand degrees, riders needing to find relief in rivers and creeks.

terrain_notes.text: The course features steep climbs at high altitude with insane vertical gain, crossing three cordilleras through Colombian jungle terrain.
Humid conditions throughout the race with challenging terrain that tests riders physically and mentally.

gear_mentions.text: Full suspension bike with drop bars and arrow bar extensions, testing dynamo hub for self-sufficient electricity generation.

race_day_tips.text: Get breakfast the night before and put it in your hotel room when starting early, fix everything yourself including cleaning the bike.
You have to be mentally and physically prepared - this race takes every single ounce of energy that you have.
Plan for extreme heat management - riders needed to find relief in rivers, creeks, and shaded areas during hot afternoon sections.

additional_quotes.text: The course is insane the ride is a super challenge but then I think for a lot of us too is the just the logistics right - getting the food every day, when you start early you have to have maybe get breakfast the night before and put it in your hotel room, you have to fix everything yourself you have to clean the bike so even if you're not pedaling then you are either eating cleaning the bike getting ready for the next day and all the logistics so it's just every day is busy
The people there are incredibly genuine and incredibly proud of where they're from it's like infectious it's really refreshing - they really appreciate where they're from and really want to share it
additional_quotes.source_channel: Far Beyond by EF Pro Cycling

rider_intel.search_text: Transcordilleras is a multi-stage Colombian Andes race covering 1055 kilometers over eight stages with 28,500 meters of elevation gain. Riders describe it as crossing three cordilleras through jungle terrain with steep climbs at high altitude and humid conditions. The ride to Puerto Berrio stands out as particularly challenging due to extreme heat requiring riders to seek relief in rivers and creeks. Logistics prove as demanding as the riding itself - daily tasks include securing food, cleaning bikes, and preparing for early starts. The non-stop category can be completed in 4.5 to 5 days with minimal sleep. Colombian riders are noted for their climbing speed and altitude adaptation. The race attracts international professionals who experience genuine Colombian hospitality. Riders emphasize the need for both mental and physical preparation as the race demands every ounce of energy over the multi-day format.
